text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Wednesday, prepared for Reuters by the Estonian news agency ETA. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- The president dismissed Interior Minister Riivo Sinijarv and ministry chancellor Jaan Toots. Toots was fired because of his use of official cars for private use; Sinijarv left reportedly for diplomatic work.
- Tiit Nuudi, manager of Paulig Baltic coffee firm, was elected president of Estonian Olympic Committee.
- Tallinn teachers will begin a strike on May 12 unless their wage rise is fully paid before the deadline.
- The daily published an interview with Paavo Lipponen, the Finnish prime minister.

- Officers will leave army service unless the state can provide them with apartments, Defence Forces Commander Johannes Kert said during visit to an army battalion with Danish Armed Forces Commander Christian Hvidt.
- Sillamae town council in the northeast called for the resignation of Mayor Priit Saksing after an investigation of suspected embezzlement began.
- The church council failed to approve the wages system proposed by the Estonian Lutheran Church to cut expenses.
- The Intel chip processor firm is considering joining the Estonian Tiger's Leap programme for computerisation of all schools.
- An Estonian businessman plans to begin breeding ostriches on the small island of Vilsandi.
- The Estonian Eurovision song contest entry was the most popular song among Internet voters.
- Parliament plans to ban advertising of tobacco products. Advertising and media experts consider this undemocratic.
- The government discussed the budget for 1998; only a rise in fuel excise was planned while administrative expenses and minimum wages were frozen.
